The benefits of cloud infra aren't just that you pay-what you use and don't need to maintain physical hardware. You also get the benefit of backend expertise dedicated to operating your infra. This manifests directly as time and cost savings for long distributed jobs on CRWV compute.

reply_context.text:
Large distributed training jobs are extremely complex systems with a lot of moving parts. It's easy to mistakenly make sub-optimal decisions that result in cost differences of thousands or millions of $$.

One of the main benefits of using cloud clusters is offloading a lot of these decisions. 

5/

* Poor temperature management can result in reduced performance and higher likelihood of device failure
* Lazy configuration decisions can result in slower network communication, causing longer step times
* Container build decisions can reduce performance of code and recovery

reply_context.text:
A GPU XYYY from one cloud provider is not the same as GPU XYYY from another. The same GPU from different manufacturers can have significantly different performance. Even from the same manufacturer, cluster and hardware configuration decisions can result in significant impacts to performance.

reply_context.text:
All cloud infra is not the same. When running a long, complex, distributed job, micro-optimizations can make a huge difference. Things like:
* network tuned for AI communication
* automated node validation and replacement to ensure all nodes available for use are healthy and stable

My team ran benchmarks using realistic LLM training workloads (llama 70B). CoreWeave infra is the fastest and most stable in the industry. Large distributed jobs survive longer w/o interruptions and recover from faults orders of magnitude faster, reducing wall time, GPU hours, and $$ to train.

posts.text:
case study:

lemonade = juice flavored by real lemons
lemon flavored sports drink = simulated juice whose imitates a real fruit (lemons)
yellow gatorade = hyperreal juice whose flavor imitates a simulated juice. "yellow" is not a flavor. 

That's Baudrillard in a nutshell. You're welcome.

reply_context.text:
sign = signifier (address) + signified (contents being addressed)
simulation = original signified is imitated, imitation assigned own signifier
hyperreal = the imitation is imitated and assigned a signifier. this signifier addresses contents which are completely ungrounded in reality.

reply_context.text: For added background: you know how you can decompose a sound wave into different speakers and instruments that comprise it? You can apply a related trick to break down 3D closed surfaces into additive components similar to how you would do it with sound (fourier transform).

reply_context.text: The number in the bottom right is essentially how "coarse" the approximation is forced to be. It starts out with low frequencies (long wavelengths), which makes the features smear/smooth out. As increasingly high frequencies are added to the approximation, the resolution of the map increases too.
